Case Study Account Team Scene Setting You have recently joined a client team as a Platform Engineer.
The existing leadership team on an account includes the Account Executive (James) and the Account Chief Architect (Sarah).
The client is a large global automotive manufacturing firm with a large wide-ranging IT estate including mainframes, factory systems, private cloud as well as public cloud capabilities. Capgemini currently provide Application management services for the Manufacturing but have also recently won the service provision for Hosting services, Cloud and some aspects of Digital development.
Client Scene Setting ABC Automotive has just defined a new Information & Technology strategy to move the organisation into the digital age. Ben, the CTO is keen to explore how he can respond to the company’s 3 priorities:
 Digital transformation Electrification Customer Centricity  Furthermore, in giving Capgemini the large contract, it has just won, he is keen to see a real shift in dial with regards to agility and pace of delivery to aid the strategic objectives above. He is keen to get:
 More agility for the technology platforms to support digital Reduction in outages being experienced by digital Audit compliance in the digital space Eradication of security breaches and non-compliant platforms being used by digital  Client Profile ABC Automotive was formed since the 1920s and has a strong heritage in car and truck production globally as a leading brand. ABC Automotive it is broadly divided into the following divisions; Manufacturing & Logistics, Enterprise, Product Creation, Commercial, Financial Planning, Corporate, Platforms, People Experience & Finance, Enterprise Digital.
IT Operating Model ABC Automotive is just rolling out a new business and IT operating model covering the retained organisation aiming to focus on building re-usable platforms to enable faster and more affordable business initiatives. Taking on a Product focus and building on platforms, they are aiming to introduce agility and close the current gap between IT and the rest of the business.
The IT Transformation unit is tasked with delivering all strategic transformation change and includes the programme delivery and management organisation.
Currently, delivery is mostly driven via a waterfall lifecycle approach, though agile and DevOps are models that the customer is increasingly looking to utilise.
Enterprise Digital Enterprise digital has already adopted the agile and digital ways of working. Over the past 3 years they have built multiple System of Engagement applications and microservices on AWS using Java / Spring. They also utilise the Atlassian suite for their development quite heavily.
Most of these are net new applications based on emerging requirements rather than replacement of existing functionality. However, there is now a strategy to replace some of the aging application estate currently Mainframe based.
Susan is keen to embrace containerisation as part of this strategic requirement for Mainframe transformation however is unclear as to how best to approach this due to the myriad of options available in the cloud market space.
The AWS land scape used by Enterprise Digital has not been structured as each digital squad have just created their own accounts, thus the environment has evolved resulting in quite a large support team across all the squads providing support and operational capabilities for patching backup and recovery etc with no standards. Security is also a challenge as a recent audit showed that they were non-compliant on patching for a lot of their Linux and Windows server instances as well as had some application code security vulnerabilities. In addition, they seem to have varying variants and versions of Linux in the environment.
Hosting Estate Within IT there was a wide range of infrastructure in use. Though most of the infrastructure is on premise, there is now a strategic shift to Cloud being driven by Ben, thus an expectation of migration of on-premise infrastructure to Cloud. The Cloud strategy is a multi-cloud one which will leverage both AWS and Azure as required. There is also a strategic drive to work closer with the Enterprise Digital teams enabling closer integration, standardisation, and transparency. Currently the service operations teams have very little knowledge of what goes on within the Enterprise Digital space and do not get visibility of any releases, roll back or technical changes until there are IT failures or outages. IT Operations utilise ServiceNow as their selected ITSM tool, but this is not used by the Enterprise Digital who have their own toolchains supporting their development pipeline as such do not report any feedback to the IT operations teams.
There current infrastructure landscape includes the following:
Data Centres
 DC1 – Owned – Uptime Institute Tier 3 certified DC2 – Owned – Uptime Institute Tier 3 certified 8 Factory based DCs across the Globe Infrastructure (On Premise) Windows servers, circa 4000 Linux, circa 3000 IBM As400, 10 Fujitsu Mainframe, 4 OpenVMS - 45 Microsoft SQL Server Database Instances, 600  Public Cloud
 Azure Server VMs - 2400 AWS Server instances, circa 850 (currently managed by Digital) MariaDB, 18

We use Hugo to format and generate our website, the Docsy theme for styling and site structure, and Azure DevOps (ADO) to manage the deployment of the site.
All submissions, including submissions by project members, require review. We use pull requests for this purpose. Consult ADO Help for more information on using pull requests.
Updating a single page If you’ve just spotted something you’d like to change while using the docs, Docsy has a shortcut for you:
 Click Edit this page in the top right hand corner of the page. If you don’t already have an up to date fork of the project repo, PLEASE CREATE ONE. The appropriate page in your fork is displayed in edit mode.  Previewing your changes locally If you want to run your own local Hugo server to preview your changes as you work:
  Follow the Hugo Quick Start to install Hugo. You’ll need at least Hugo version 0.45 (we recommend using the most recent available version), and it must be the extended version, which supports SCSS.
  Download and install node.js
  Fork the Chapter repo repo into your own project, then create a local copy using git clone. Don’t forget to use --recurse-submodules or you won’t pull down some of the code you need to generate a working site.
git clone --recurse-submodules --depth 1 https://dev.azure.com/robdyke0245/_git/chapter   Run hugo server in the site root directory. By default your site will be available at http://localhost:1313/. Now that you’re serving your site locally, Hugo will watch for changes to the content and automatically refresh your site.
  Continue with the usual Git PR workflow to edit files, commit them, push the changes up to your fork, and create a pull request.
  Creating an issue If you’ve found a problem in the docs, but you’re not sure how to fix it yourself, please create an issue in the Chapter repo. You can also create an issue about a specific page by clicking the Create Issue button in the top right hand corner of the page.
Useful resources  Docsy user guide: All about Docsy, including how it manages navigation, look and feel, and multi-language support. Hugo documentation: Comprehensive reference for Hugo. Github Hello World!: A basic introduction to GitHub concepts and workflow.

Vagrant provides easy to configure, reproducible, and portable work environments. Automagically. To achieve this, Vagrant stands on the shoulders of giants. Machines are provisioned on top of VirtualBox, VMware, AWS, and other providers. Then, industry-standard provisioning tools such as shell scripts, Chef, or Puppet, can automatically install and configure software on the virtual machine.
 Download from https://www.vagrantup.com/downloads.html
Quick start for Windows 10  Enable Hyper-V Download and run the Vagrant installer Launch Powershell (as Administrator) and navigate to a folder of your choice Initialise an Ubuntu environment using Hyper-V  vagrant init hashicorp/bionic64   Launch the box  vagrant up   SSH to the box  vagrant ssh    Recommended VS Code Extensions  Vagrantfile Support (Marco Stazi)  Things to do Version control your environment
 Commit the Vagrantfile to a repo  Optimise performance
 Use vendor extentions? More memory? Copy or cloned disks?  Provision the environment
 Update the operating system Install software - eg nginx for a webserver Forward network ports - eg access the webserver on port 8080  Vagrantfile examples Minimal Vagrantfile
Vagrant.configure("2") do |config| config.vm.box = "hashicorp/bionic64" end Using a provisioner
Vagrant.configure("2") do |config| config.vm.box = "hashicorp/bionic64" # Define the box config.vm.box_check_update = false # Don't check for updates to the box config.vm.provider "hyperv" do |h| h.enable_virtualization_extensions = true # Use Hyper-V extensions h.linked_clone = true # Use cloned disks h.memory = "1024" # Use 1G RAM end config.vm.synced_folder ".", "/vagrant", disabled: true # Don't mount a sync folder config.ssh.insert_key = false # Don't insert new SSH key, keep the INSECURE default key config.vm.provision "shell", inline: <<-SHELL # Update the box apt-get update apt-get upgrade -y SHELL end

Platform Engineering Chapter The platform engineering chapter in CIS aims to enable customers to build and operate platforms on hybrid cloud environments. In order to succeed in this, the skills and culture need to be developed and integrated into the way that engineers at Capgemini deliver service.
Chapter The chapter is focusing on developing the attitude and priciples essential to successful platform engineering teams’ ways of working.
The original Spotify paper in 2012, described the underlying concept of chapters:
Chapters: Henrik Kniberg & Anders Ivarsson, Spotify 2012   A key tenant though is Aligned Autonomy
The Platform Engineering Chapter is therefore focusing on CIS SME’s and Architects, working closing with the rest of Capgemini, to identify and develop the skills and capabilities required to be able to deliver the best platforms for customers.
Capgemini and our customers have a multitude of platform engineering teams, with the knowledge and experience captured within different business units, and knowledge repositories. The Chapter is also looking to facilitate the sharing and awareness of these.
Platform Engineering As organisations migrate their IT workloads to various types of public, private and hybrid clouds, platform teams have evolved. A core focus of all organisations is to enable the application (or ‘product’) teams to be more efficient and effective, delivering quality business features quicker. Tjhere are a multitude of views in how that efficiency could be achieved, such as the papter from Peter Seibel or the description from ThoughtWorks
An initial architectural overview to consider from the CIS perspective is
  Whereby the platform team will develop accelerators and stacks to provide environments that support the application and data engineering team
Growth & Development In order to achive this the Chapter is looking to
 Develop skills Develop accelerators for platform deployments and operation  The training programes and accelerators to deliver on this capability is captured throughout this site.

This is a generated static site The first website I hand-crafted with Notepad was a static web site. Painfully static. Made slightly less painful with version control and helper bash scripts. I was an early convert to web content management systems with WYSIWYG editors such as Drupal & Wordpress. Until I had to run them at scale.
This site is built using Hugo, a general-purpose website framework written in Go. Technically speaking, Hugo is a static site generator. Unlike systems that dynamically build a page with each visitor request, Hugo builds pages when you create or update your content.
Show the thing The content is written in markdown, stored in a git repo in Azure DevOps and published using a release pipeline.
